section.title: dbconfig-common package
section.para: The dbconfig-common package provides a standard Debian interface that enables you to configure Debian database parameters. It includes localized prompts for many languages and it supports OpenStack-supported database back ends, which are SQLite, MySQL, and PostgreSQL.

By default, the dbconfig-common system will configure your packages to use SQLite3. So if you use debconf in non-interactive mode without using pre-seeding, the OpenStack services that you install will be using SQLite3.

By default, dbconfig-common does not provide access to database servers over a network. If you want the dbconfig-common package to prompt for remote database servers that are accessed over a network and not through a UNIX socket file, you must reconfigure it, as follows:

Unlike other debconf prompts, you cannot pre-seed the answers for the dbconfig-common prompts by using debconf-set-selections. Instead, you must create a file in /etc/dbconfig-common. For example, you might create a keystone configuration file for dbconfig-common that is located in /etc/dbconfig-common/keystone.conf:
section.programlisting: dbc_install='true' dbc_upgrade='true' dbc_remove='' dbc_dbtype='mysql' dbc_dbuser='keystone' dbc_dbpass='MyKeyStoneDbPassWord' dbc_dbserver='' dbc_dbport='' dbc_dbname='keystonedb' dbc_dbadmin='root' dbc_basepath='' dbc_ssl='' dbc_authmethod_admin='' dbc_authmethod_user=''
